column4: description
The system that circulates blood throughout the body; delivering oxygen and nutrients to cells and removing waste products.
The system responsible for gas exchange; taking in oxygen and expelling carbon dioxide.
The complex network that coordinates body activities by transmitting signals between different body parts.
The framework of bones and connective tissues that supports the body; protects organs; and enables movement.
The system of muscles that enables movement; maintains posture; and generates heat.
The system that breaks down food into nutrients for absorption and eliminates waste.
column15: About 9 meters (30 feet) from mouth to anus

column4: The collection of glands that produce hormones to regulate metabolism; growth; development; and other functions.
The complex network that defends the body against pathogens and other threats.
A muscular organ that pumps blood through the circulatory system by rhythmic contraction and dilation.
The primary organs of respiration; where gas exchange occurs between the air and blood.
The central organ of the nervous system; responsible for processing sensory information and controlling bodily functions and behaviors.
The largest internal organ; performing hundreds of functions including detoxification; protein synthesis; and digestion.
Bean-shaped organs that filter blood to produce urine; regulate electrolytes; and maintain acid-base balance.
A muscular; hollow organ that holds food and begins the digestion of proteins.
The long; coiled tube where most digestion and nutrient absorption occurs.
A glandular organ that secretes digestive enzymes and hormones like insulin and glucagon.
An organ that filters blood and helps defend against pathogens as part of the immune system.
The bony structure that forms the head; encases the brain; and supports facial structures.
The flexible column of vertebrae that protects the spinal cord and supports the head and body.
The bony cage formed by the sternum; ribs; and thoracic vertebrae that protects vital organs.
The thigh bone; the longest and strongest bone in the human body.
Specialized involuntary muscle tissue found only in the heart; allowing for coordinated contractions.
A dome-shaped skeletal muscle that separates the thoracic and abdominal cavities and is essential for breathing.
A large muscle located on the front of the upper arm; primarily responsible for forearm flexion and supination.
column16: Anterior compartment of the upper arm

column4: A group of four muscles on the front of the thigh that extend the knee.
The largest artery in the body; carrying oxygenated blood from the left ventricle of the heart to the body.
column36: Distribution of oxygenated blood throughout the body

column4: The arteries that supply blood to the heart muscle.
The arteries that carry deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs.
column36: Transport of deoxygenated blood to lungs for oxygenation
column42: One of the few arteries carrying deoxygenated blood

column4: The largest veins in the body; returning deoxygenated blood to the right atrium of the heart.
column37: Return of deoxygenated blood to the heart

column4: The cylindrical bundle of nerve fibers that extends from the brain and is protected by the vertebral column.
column38: Conduction of neural signals between brain and body; reflex center

column4: The 10th cranial nerve; with the widest distribution in the body; controlling parasympathetic functions.
column36: Parasympathetic control of heart; lungs; digestive tract; sensory information from viscera

column4: The largest and longest nerve in the body; running from the lower back down through the leg.
column36: Motor and sensory innervation of lower limb

column4: A small region of the brain that coordinates both the autonomic nervous system and the endocrine system.
The basic functional unit of the nervous system; specialized for transmitting information.
column24: Approximately 86 billion in the human brain

column4: The most common type of blood cell; responsible for oxygen transport.
Cardiac muscle cells that make up the heart muscle.
The tissue that forms the outer layer of the body and lines organs and cavities.
column23: Skin surface; organ linings; gland secretory units
